Literature Review: Mutation rate variability in plant genomes is a complex phenomenon that has garnered significant attention in recent years. The variability in mutation rates across different mutation types, genome locations, gene functions, epigenomic contexts, environmental conditions, genotypes, and species has been observed and studied extensively. This variability arises from differential rates of DNA damage, repair, and transposable element activation and insertion, which together contribute to the measured DNA mutation rates. In this review, we will discuss the historical and recent investigations into the causes and consequences of mutation rate variability in plants, focusing on the mechanisms that shape this variation. We will also explore emerging mechanistic models that point to the evolvability of mutation rate variation across genomes via mechanisms that target DNA repair, and discuss the implications of these findings for plant evolution and breeding.
